results.title: Robert Klippel. 1. Junk sculpture, 1963
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: A sculpture by Robert Klippel incorporating parts of discarded machinery with forms cut from sheet metal. The film is cut to a dodecaphonic composition for piano. Music: Larry Sitsky.

results.title: Robert Klippel drawings, 1947-1963
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: A succession of the drawings of the Australian sculptor, Robert Klippel, covering the period from 1947-1963. Shows the development of the creative talent - an exploration of the mind of a fascinating man, the things which inspired him and the many strange, abstract drawings which were the result of his experiences in Australia and overseas. The commentary is by Klippel himself. Music by Larry Sitsky.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill

results.title: Robert Klippel
results.creator_credit: Keith Salvat, Keisal Films and Australia Council
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Robert Klippel is viewed as one of Australia’s most important artists of the fifties and sixties. His humble beginnings (and obsession) with ship modelmaking was to influence and inform his work throughout his career as an artist. Klippel was a self-taught artist whose interest sprung from the processes he’d developed while model building, a scale which was to continue in his work throughout his career. Klippel had a strong preference for the solid built form of sculpture but found his work naturally becoming more linear in style. His developed language in the fifties and his need for intellectual peers saw him travel to Europe and New York to again resettle in Sydney, Australia where he developed strong artistic allies and his notoriety as an abstract expressionist artist along with Olsen and Passmore. This documentary charts Klippel’s role in a developing cultural nation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Salvat, Keisal Films and Australia Council

results.title: Robert Indiana: portrait
results.brief_description: A film about Robert Indiana; the artist and his art, and the meaning in language. One of the best known “pop” artists in America, Robert Indiana gives his opinions and feelings on not just his art, but life in general, and his studio, paintings and everyday life are seen. Highly recommended to classes in both art and language arts. Music by Virgil Thomson.

results.title: Robert Frost: a first acquaintance
results.creator_credit: Films for the Humanities and Harold Mantell
results.brief_description: Describes how the poems which first made American poet Robert Frost famous were based on his experiences as a farmer in New England. Shows Frost reading his poems to a student audience, and his daughter, Lesley Frost, discussing some of Frost’s poems and his poetic theories. Suitable for middle and upper seconday levels.

results.title: Robert Frost's The death of the hired man
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Jeanne Collachla
results.brief_description: An adaptation of Robert Frost’s narrative poem of the same title about an aged and no longer productive hired man, who returns to live on a couple’s farm. The film captures the couple’s apprehension over the fate of the proud, homeless man amid scenes depciting early 20th century farm life in New England.

results.title: Robert D. Fitzgerald
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Acclaimed poet Robert D. Fitzgerald describes himself as a “professional surveyor and an amateur poet”. He recalls his experiences working for the Native Lands Commission in the remote interior regions of Fiji which inspired his poem “Between two tides”. Fitzgerald remembers his friendship with fellow writers Kenneth Slessor, Jack and Phillip Lindsay, Douglas Stewart and Dame Mary Gilmore. During the Vietnam war, Fitzgerald was active in the anti-war movement. He discusses the reasons for his involvement and recalls the events surrounding the Arts Vietnam protest.

results.title: Robert Browning: his life and poetry
results.brief_description: Surveys the biography and works of the Victorian poet Robert Browning, focussing on the revelation of dramatic monologue. The film shows the things from which Browning drew his inspiration and uses paintings, early photographs and scenes of unchanged parts of London and Italy to illustrate the events of his life. Selections of his poetry are read by constumed actors, emphasising the drama and psychological insight of his work. Narrated by Andrew Faulds.
